CAN Staff Members Hannah Klinnert, Executive Director Sarah VanStedum, Program Leader Brenda Hasler, Operations Director Dawn Callahan, Program Leader Jissell Cano, Program Assistant Gregory Zelasko, Program Assistant Vanessa Maduzia, Program Advisor Kimberly Nierman, Intern Supervisor & Program Leader Andrew Zelasko, Program Leader Christina Stauffer, Program Leader Delani Kosner, Program Assistant Joseph Kim, Program Assistant Gia Hanrahan, Intern Coordinator & Program Leader Diana Chrostowski, Community Relations Coordinator Amy Ranalli, Program Assistant CAN's Administrative Board of Directors: CAN's Advisory Board : Vivienne Venderley Jennifer Fairlamb Jeanette Edwards Sherry Healey Jama Wall Mark Brown Justin Elder Peggy Kulling Mary Muszynski Subscribe to Newsletter Recent Newsletter CAN's Annual Financial Report Like us on Facebook 25 E Benton Ave Naperville, IL  60540 Info@communityaccessnaperville.org 630-352-1928 Community Access Naperville is a 501c3 not-for-profit organization. Donations are tax-deductible to the full amount permitted by law. bottom of page

We have 66 local vendors selling handcrafted items and our famous hot dog lunch featuring a hot dog, drink and chips. Turkey Creek Day FREE Saturday, April 19 - 8:30 am to 3 pm A FREE family fun day! Local craft vendors - Environmental Groups Children's storytime, with a special guest Games for the kids - Balloon Twister Scavenger hunt - Nature Tours Our famous hot dog lunch featuring a hot dog, drink and a bag of chips, will be on sale. Kids to Park Day FREE Saturday, May 17 - 9 to 10am Join us for a special kids hike in the Sanctuary. The hike will include a visit to "tortoise town" to talk about these amazing reptiles. Parents are asked to join their children for this tour. Park after Dark FREE SAVE THE DATE Saturday, November, 15 - 6 to 9:30 pm Our third annual event. Live music, vendors, food trucks and lots of fun. Copyright © 2023 Turkey Creek Sanctuary Society, Inc. - All Rights Reserved. Twice Monthly Nature Tours - Turkey Creek Sanctuary Society QUESTIONS? Visit our FAQ page to find your answers! 321.676.6690 321.676.6690 Sign In Create Account Bookings Orders My Account Signed in as: filler@godaddy.com Bookings Orders My Account Sign out Signed in as: filler@godaddy.com Home The Nature Center Dog Policy Classes / Planks / Events Coming Events Nature Tours Donations and Store Biking at Turkey Creek Kayak Tour Volunteer Opportunities FAQ Contact Account Bookings Orders My Account Sign out Sign In Bookings Orders My Account TWICE-MONTHLY NATURE TOUR TWICE-MONTHLY NATURE TOUR Monthly Nature Tours are FREE! Nature Tours are on the first and third Sundays of every month. The tour is approximately 1-1/2 hours, and we walk about 1 mile. These tours are for individuals and families. If your organization or group is interested in a tour, please contact the nature center at 321.676.6690 Tours are subject to cancellation due to weather. If the weather is bad, please call the nature center to confirm there will be a tour. If there is active lightening in the area the tour will be cancelled! Sanctuary Society Website! Welcome to the Turkey Creek
Sanctuary Society Website! Welcome to the Turkey Creek
Sanctuary Society Website! Welcome to the Turkey Creek
Sanctuary Society Website! Welcome to the Turkey Creek
Sanctuary Society Website! QUESTIONS? Visit the FAQ page for answers. Turkey Creek Sanctuary | Palm Bay, Florida TURKEY CREEK SANCTUARY PARK The park property was donated to the City of Palm Bay and the Florida Audubon Society in 1978 by the General Development Corporation i n partnership with Florida Communities Trust .  Later, in 2004, Brevard County's Environmentally Endangered Land Program added acreage to the Sanctuary. Now, the Sanctuary consists of 130 acres of undeveloped, native Florida land The Sanctuary stands on a small section of what was once an ancient Atlantic Ocean dune. This dune is part of a series of dunes formed by wind and wave action when the ocean extended across the state. Through the ages, life, death, and decay have gradually enriched the sand so that a forest stands where only sea oats could survive. Our Sanctuary is a refuge for native Florida plants like sand pines, scrub and turkey oaks, cactus, wire grass, scrub paw paw, large flower rosemary, and more. In addition to the plant life, the Sanctuary is also home to many species of native Florida wildlife, such as manatees, alligators, gopher tortoises, and bobcats. As a part of The Great Florida Birding and Wildlife Trail , many species of birds can be seen while walking through the Sanctuary. TURKEY CREEK SANCTUARY SOCIETY Efforts to preserve Turkey Creek Sanctuary began in 1981 with the formation of a citizen support group.  This group still exists today as the Turkey Creek Sanctuary Society, Inc., a registered 501(c)3 non-profit, and a proud Community Partner of the City of Palm Bay. OUR MISSION The sole purpose of the Turkey Creek Sanctuary Society is to raise funds to support the improvement and upkeep of  Turkey Creek Sanctuary and to educate the community on the vital importance and the many benefits of Florida wildlife and its natural environment. Stay in touch with our newsletter, "The Creek" Enter your email below to sign up for our quarterly newsletter. Email Subscribe In the end, our society will be defined not only by what we create, but by what we refuse to destroy. John Sawhill Copyright © 2023 Turkey Creek Sanctuary Society, Inc. - All Rights Reserved. About Us Current vacancies (new tab) News England Scotland Manage your home Information for residents Your home Back Your home Repair responsibilities for renters Repair responsibilities for homeowners Condensation, damp and mould Bed bugs in your home Safety in your home Improving your home Home insurance Your home and the environment Factored Owners Your tenancy Back Your tenancy Responsibilities Changes to your household Swapping your home Moving out Permissions Tenancy fraud Next of Kin Your payments Back Your payments Make a payment Help with making a payment Housing Benefit and Universal Credit Service charges Your Neighbourhood Back Your neighbourhood Bulky waste and fly tipping Household waste Abandoned or Empty properties Help and support Back Help and support Complaints Safeguarding Cost of living help Domestic Abuse Report a repair Discover your options to report a repair Find out more Find a home Find a home Rent a home Buy a home Mid-market rent Sheltered housing More housing and support Back Care homes Student accommodation Technology-enabled care Get involved Contact us Contact us Report a repair Make a payment Complaints Freedom of Information Media enquiries General enquiries Connect to a British Sign Language interpreter Customer Hub Open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week including public holidays for emergency repairs. Find out more Search Search the website Topic Corporate news Customer news Type Customer News Corporate News Customer Stories Staff Stories Sort by Newest First Oldest First Home Contact us On this page Toggle table of contents panel Need to talk to us? Our Customer Hub is open 24 hours a day, seven days a week, including public holidays for emergency repairs . For housing enquiries, we are open Monday to Friday, 8am to 5pm. Customer enquiries Contact us by telephone Call us on: 0808 168 3475​​​​​​​ Enquiry form: For any non-urgent general enquiries, please use our online enquiry form Repairs: To raise a repair, please complete our repairs enquiry webform Social media How can we help? If you have a question or concern, the most convenient way to tell us is by filling out our online form. Our online form enables us to receive your message and respond to you as quickly as possible. We value your feedback and suggestions and are committed to addressing any issues. Our team is always ready to help and provide you with any information you need. Online enquiry form Contact us in writing England: Sanctuary House, Chamber Court, Castle Street, Worcester, Worcestershire, WR1 3ZQ Scotland: Sanctuary Scotland, 7 Freeland Drive, Glasgow, G53 6PG Quick links to other useful information and webforms Image Repairs Learn about our repairs process and how to raise an issue. Image Rent and payments Find out more about the ways you can pay your rent. Image Antisocial behaviour Find out what is classed as antisocial behaviour and how to report it. Image Moving out Learn what you need to when you move out of your property. Alternative formats At Sanctuary, we are committed to making our services accessible to everyone. We offer a range of different formats for our communications, so you can access all the information you need in a way that suits you. Translation services We understand that visitors to our website may come from different backgrounds and speak different languages. If English is not your first language, or if you do not speak English, our translation services are here to assist you. Our translators are available 24/7 and can provide translations for over 60 languages. They can help with phone conversations and translate letters and documents. We want to ensure that everyone can easily read and understand the information on our website. To assist with this, we have provided guides on how to translate our website (and other websites) using different web browsers. Google Chrome Google Chrome offers a built-in translation feature that allows you to translate a webpage into your preferred language. Follow these simple steps to enable this feature: Open the Google Chrome browser. Visit the webpage you want to translate. Right-click on the webpage, then select "Translate to [Language]" from the context menu. For detailed instructions, visit Google's Support Page: How to Translate Webpages in Google Chrome. Microsoft Edge For those using the Microsoft Edge browser, translation can be as easy as a click of a button. Here's how to do it: Open the Microsoft Edge browser. Visit the webpage you want to translate. Click on the "..." (More) button in the top-right corner of the browser window. Select "Translate to [Language]" from the drop-down menu. For detailed instructions, visit Microsoft's Support Page: Use Microsoft Translator in Microsoft Edge Browser. Safari If you are using a Mac and your browser of choice is Safari, you can easily translate webpages into your desired language by following these steps: Open the Safari browser. Visit the webpage you want to translate. Click on the "View" menu in the top bar and select "Translation". For detailed instructions, you can visit Apple's Support Page: How to Translate Webpages in Safari. It is important to keep in mind that while these tools are very helpful, they may not always provide a perfect translation. They might miss some of the finer details and context, but they should still give you a good understanding of what's on our webpage. Helpline for people who are deaf or hard of hearing If you are deaf or hard of hearing, our Customer Hub offers the following services: Text relay service: 07800 006781 Connect to a British Sign Language interpreter Written communication If you would like to access our written communications in a different format, we offer a range of different formats to suit your needs and preferences. This includes: Braille Large print Audio versions of our communications (if you would prefer to listen rather than read) Electronic formats, such as accessible Word docx files, PDFs, and HTML, which can be customised to suit you. Helpful information Keeping your details secure Important information: We are aware that people sometimes contact residents without their consent by means of cold calling. While this is sadly not within our control we can assure you that we take data protection extremely seriously and would not disclose any information under any circumstances without your permission. The only information we would ask you for when contacting you would be your names, address, DOB and telephone number. In some cases, we may also ask for your National Insurance number. We would never ask for bank account details, passwords or other such sensitive information, nor would we ask you to pay a courier in cash or request remote access to your computer/mobile/tablet. Find out more about keeping your personal details secure . IFF Research – Phone and Email Surveys We have partnered with independent market researchers, IFF Research, to learn what you think about Sanctuary and our services. If you are a Sanctuary Housing or Supported Living resident, IFF Research may phone or email you to ask you what you think about us. If they contact you by email, the email will be from myresearch@voluntas.co.uk . The survey takes no more than 10 minutes, and all answers are completely confidential. We will only know you were surveyed if you give IFF Research permission to share your details with us. The full results of our surveys will be shared with the Regulator of Social Housing. This activity supports the new Tenant Satisfaction Measures introduced by the Regulator in April 2023. Please see our privacy statement for full details about how your personal data will be used. Call charges The 0800 number shown above is free. For the exact call and text charges from your mobile phone or landline for other numbers, please check with your provider. Feedback We welcome your comments about our services. If you have any feedback about Sanctuary, please complete our online feedback form. Sanctuary careers If you are interested in working for Sanctuary, please visit our Careers pages where information about careers and current vacancies within the organisation can be found. Please visit our Apprenticeships and Graduates pages for more information about each programme. Media enquiries and contacts If you are member of the media, visit our Press Office page for more information, or contact the Press Office by email: pr@sanctuary-housing.co.uk The Press Office does not have direct access to customer information and is unable to answer customer enquiries. It is also not able to answer questions about careers and vacancies. Social Media For information on how to get in touch with us on social media, please visit our Media page for a full list of our official social media accounts. Become a volunteer -  Turkey Creek Sanctuary Society QUESTIONS? Visit our FAQ page to find your answers! 321.676.6690 321.676.6690 Sign In Create Account Bookings Orders My Account Signed in as: filler@godaddy.com Bookings Orders My Account Sign out Signed in as: filler@godaddy.com Home The Nature Center Dog Policy Classes / Planks / Events Coming Events Nature Tours Donations and Store Biking at Turkey Creek Kayak Tour Volunteer Opportunities FAQ Contact Account Bookings Orders My Account Sign out Sign In Bookings Orders My Account Become a volunteer VOLUNTEER APPLICATION PROCESS Volunteers run our Nature Center. The center is not open if we have no volunteer for a scheduled shift. Consider becoming a volunteer to help us remain open during our intended hours. All you need is a friendly smile, a pleasant attitude, and an appreciation for Turkey Creek Sanctuary. If you're interested in becoming a Volunteer at the Nature Center, complete the Online Application below or come to the Nature Center during our open hours. One of our Volunteers can help you fill out the form. ONLINE APPLICATION The minimum age to volunteer is 18. There is no maximum age! To complete and submit your application online, follow the process below: Download, edit, and complete the Palm Bay Volunteer Service Corps (PBVSC) application . Scan (if filled out by hand) and save it on your computer to upload through our website. Fill out the Turkey Creek Sanctuary Volunteer Information Request Form to submit your completed PBVSC application and your schedule and interests to the Park and the Nature Center staff. * *Must have a valid Driver's License or State ID and be able to pass a background check.** Connect With Us Copyright © 2023 Turkey Creek Sanctuary Society, Inc. - All Rights Reserved. A boardwalk natural trail twists and turns along the murky, bass-filled black water creek, a major stopover for spring and fall migratory birds including the woodpecker and rare purple martin amongst other wildlife. For a place to get outside and enjoy the scenic landscape, Turkey Creek Sanctuary provides that and more. The on-site nature center provides educational interpretive exhibits and a gift shop where you can take home a souvenir to commemorate your time there. About Us -Turkey Creek Sanctuary Society QUESTIONS? Visit our FAQ page to find your answers! 321.676.6690 321.676.6690 Sign In Create Account Bookings Orders My Account Signed in as: filler@godaddy.com Bookings Orders My Account Sign out Signed in as: filler@godaddy.com Home The Nature Center Dog Policy Classes / Planks / Events Coming Events Nature Tours Donations and Store Biking at Turkey Creek Kayak Tour Volunteer Opportunities FAQ Contact Account Bookings Orders My Account Sign out Sign In Bookings Orders My Account About Us Kayaking Turkey Creek Sanctuary Turkey Creek is an oasis within the city of Palm Bay. It runs from the Melbourne-Tillman Dam north to the Indian River, approximately 3 miles. The creek is a “lazy river” most days requiring easy paddling. High water levels or wind can make the paddling a bit more challenging. Always check the weather prior to beginning any kayak trip. Wear your floatation vest, and bring a good hat, sunscreen, bug spray, and plenty of water. Pull-out areas with restrooms and/or picnic areas are identified on the detailed maps below . Be sure to look up, down, and listen during your trip! There is an abundant variety of birds in the trees along the creek, mammals on the banks, plus fish and reptiles. Please take only photos and good memories. Most importantly, have fun!! Geography and History Turkey Creek is a major tributary of the Indian River Lagoon. The creek mouth forms a bay surrounded by palms from which the city was named. The creek is fed by an extensive canal system covering 100 square miles of land, draining into the Tillman Dam. While the creek is normally slow-moving, it can become engorged after heavy rains and thus move swiftly. Turkey Creek is a brackish water creek, whose natural brown coloring comes from tannins in the leaves of oak trees that have fallen in the water. Beneath the wet hammock along the banks of the creek is a unique geological rock stratum called the “Anastasia Formation”. Perched on this limestone rock is a bed of fossil bones over 250,000 years old. Click the links below to access the self-guided kayaking routes and enjoy! Paddling Route 1: Turkey Creek Sanctuary Turkey Creek Sanctuary is comprised of 133 acres of wonder, biodiversity and natural resources. The park is part of the Brevard County Environmentally Endangered Lands (EEL) Program and the East Florida Birding Trail. It was established in 1978 when the land was donated to the City of Palm Bay and the Florida Audubon Society by the General Development Corporation.  All plants and animals are protected. No fishing is allowed on this stretch. Paddling Route 2:  Turkey Creek Sanctuary to Indian River Approximately 2 hour round trip through the straight, wider section of the creek. This section goes by housing, several bays and ends at the Indian River. Keep an eye out for dolphin and manatee in the bays. Castaway Point is home to beautiful water birds and has a small beach. Download Kayaking Information Click below to download a PDF of the guided tours. Brochure of Kayak Route 1 (pdf) Download Brochure of Kayak Route 2 (pdf) Download Brochure of Kayak Routes and Map Overview (pdf) Download Connect With Us Copyright © 2023 Turkey Creek Sanctuary Society, Inc. - All Rights Reserved. Sanctuary Society Website! QUESTIONS? Visit the FAQ page for answers. Turkey Creek Sanctuary | Palm Bay, Florida TURKEY CREEK SANCTUARY PARK The park property was donated to the City of Palm Bay and the Florida Audubon Society in 1978 by the General Development Corporation i n partnership with Florida Communities Trust .  Later, in 2004, Brevard County's Environmentally Endangered Land Program added acreage to the Sanctuary. Now, the Sanctuary consists of 130 acres of undeveloped, native Florida land The Sanctuary stands on a small section of what was once an ancient Atlantic Ocean dune. This dune is part of a series of dunes formed by wind and wave action when the ocean extended across the state. Through the ages, life, death, and decay have gradually enriched the sand so that a forest stands where only sea oats could survive. Our Sanctuary is a refuge for native Florida plants like sand pines, scrub and turkey oaks, cactus, wire grass, scrub paw paw, large flower rosemary, and more. In addition to the plant life, the Sanctuary is also home to many species of native Florida wildlife, such as manatees, alligators, gopher tortoises, and bobcats. As a part of The Great Florida Birding and Wildlife Trail , many species of birds can be seen while walking through the Sanctuary. TURKEY CREEK SANCTUARY SOCIETY Efforts to preserve Turkey Creek Sanctuary began in 1981 with the formation of a citizen support group.  This group still exists today as the Turkey Creek Sanctuary Society, Inc., a registered 501(c)3 non-profit, and a proud Community Partner of the City of Palm Bay. OUR MISSION The sole purpose of the Turkey Creek Sanctuary Society is to raise funds to support the improvement and upkeep of  Turkey Creek Sanctuary and to educate the community on the vital importance and the many benefits of Florida wildlife and its natural environment. Stay in touch with our newsletter, "The Creek" Enter your email below to sign up for our quarterly newsletter. Email Subscribe In the end, our society will be defined not only by what we create, but by what we refuse to destroy. John Sawhill Copyright © 2023 Turkey Creek Sanctuary Society, Inc. - All Rights Reserved. Our Team – Critter Creek Farm Sanctuary Our Team The Critter Creek Farm Sanctuary team consists of a group of primarily volunteer workers who donate their time, energy, money, and love to keep CCFS up and running. None of the board members draws a salary for their board duties. Our team is rounded out by veterinarian Dr. Joe Guevara. Though he is officially considered an independent contractor and not a staff member, Dr. Joe has worked with CCFS from the very beginning and works closely with the sanctuary to advise on all manner of health issues. Whether it's walking the fields to remove potentially harmful plants or showing up on a Sunday (and his wedding anniversary) for a sick pig, Dr. Joe has always been there for us. Erin Amerman Founder, Board President Erin founded Critter Creek Farm Sanctuary with three rescued cows in 2016, and is currently president of the Board of Directors. Her road to rescue started where most such things naturally begin: with a rat. At age 7, her mother told her she could finally have her first pet, a hamster. Ecstatic, she went to the pet store to pick out her hamster. But as she held a couple hamsters, who only wanted to pee on her, bite her, or run away from her, a young woman working at the pet store asked her if she had ever considered a rat. She and her mother exchanged looks. A rat? People have pet rats? The young woman explained that rats are wonderful little animals, but no one gives them a chance because they are unfairly judged to be bad and unworthy. Erin held the rat, and he was sweet. There was no biting, there was no running away. He did pee on her, though. Guess which animal she came home with? That rat, named Templeton, taught her a lot about how society can treat very differently two species of animal who would seem to be very similar... You can read the rest of Erin's bio and story here . Chris Amerman Co-Founder, Board Treasurer, and Sanctuary Director Chris met Erin at the University of West Florida in 1995 and they married in 1997. Always an animal lover, he gave up animal products shortly after they married when he ran out of arguments against it. While in medical school, they began volunteering for a no-kill animal shelter and rescuing cats and dogs, which has continued to this day. Through the years, Chris has usually tried to be the voice of reason about their rescues, but Erin generally isn't very good at listening. At CCFS, Chris is Treasurer of the Board of Directors and the Sanctuary Director. He has also developed something of a donkey problem. In this case, Erin tries to be the voice of reason, but Chris generally isn't very good at listening, either. Colin Callahan Facilities Manager, Animal Care Specialist Colin joined Critter Creek Farm Sanctuary in early 2020 as a volunteer. A geneticist by trade, Colin has worked as a bench scientist at institutions such as Johns Hopkins University and the University of Florida. However, in 2024, due to his love of animals and dedication to the sanctuary’s mission, he decided it was time for a career change and came to work for the sanctuary full-time. He is currently the facilities manager and primary caretaker at the Critter Creek facility, where he maintains the grounds, prepares the facility for events, maintains infrastructure, performs vehicle and small engine maintenance, and carefully monitors the animal residents’ health and wellbeing. Colin has a B.S. degree in microbiology and cell science from the University of Florida and a Master of Science in ecology with an emphasis on population genetics from Utah State University. Meredith Berry Science Director, Interim Board Secretary Dr. Meredith Berry is a professor at the University of Florida in the Health and Human Performance department, with special interests in conservation psychology, behavioral research in decision-making, and behavioral economics. She began volunteering for Critter Creek in 2020, and in 2024, she was invited to join the Board. Her background in conservation science and experimental psychology makes her a great asset to the sanctuary’s conservation and science programs, and in October 2024, she directed the first-ever study on sanctuaries as advocacy tools. Meredith completed her postdoctoral training at Johns Hopkins University. She has a Ph.D. in forest and conservation sciences from the University of Montana, an M.S. in experimental psychology from Utah State University, and a B.S. in Psychology from the University of Florida. The author of over 50 scientific publications, her research is frequently covered in popular press news outlets such as Scientific American, Pacific Standard Magazine, Fast Company Magazine, and The Huffington Post. Katelyn Braglia Volunteer Coordinator, Humane Educator Growing up in Jupiter Farms, FL, Katelyn developed a lifelong love for the outdoors, participating in youth service-learning camps hosted by a local wildlife sanctuary. After relocating to Nevada with her family, she combined her passions for nature and education—working at both a wildlife sanctuary and a preschool center while attending the University of Nevada, Reno. She volunteered at her first farm animal sanctuary in Las Vegas after graduating with her bachelors. The bonds she formed with the resident animals during her time solidified her dedication to activism, humane education, and compassionate animal care. When Katelyn returned to Florida in December 2023, she was excited to connect with the Critter Creek community after following them on social media. After a year of volunteering, she officially joined the team in December 2024 as Volunteer Coordinator and Humane Educator. With a B.S. in Human Development and Family Studies, minor in Developmental Disabilities, and experience as a middle school science teacher, Katelyn now gets to combine her love of teaching with her commitment to animals—creating an accessible and positive experience for humans and animals alike! Please reach out to katelyn at katelyn@crittercreekfarmsanctuary.org for volunteer and education inquiries. Gretchen Sumrall Executive Assistant, Animal Care Specialist Gretchen joined the Critter Creek team in May 2025 after transitioning from her job as a USDA Chemical Ecology Assistant to pursue her passion for animal care. She now serves as Executive Assistant, supporting the sanctuary through a blend of hands-on animal care and behind-the-scenes business operations. Gretchen works closely with the team to help ensure the sanctuary runs smoothly—from feeding donkeys to organizing files. While she loves all the animals at Critter Creek, she has a special fondness for the donkeys and knows each one by their quirks. Outside of work, Gretchen enjoys autumnal walks with her dog, Duckie, taking her cat Sylvie on leash walks, and listening to Taylor Swift. Samantha M. Bennett-Clark Equine Manager Samantha joined the team in December 2019. She found her way to Critter Creek a few months prior when she urgently needed to find a home for two heifers, Jingles and Bella. Samantha graduated from the University of Florida with a bachelor’s degree in Animal Sciences and Plant Science and a minor in Agricultural and Natural Resources Law. An equine wizard, Samantha has been Critter Creek's equine manager since 2021. Samantha is also a bovine wizard, and she remains the only person who can handle our resident terror-bird, Cletus. When she isn’t working on the sanctuary or studying, Samantha enjoys spending time with her cats, steer, and horses. © Critter Creek Farm Sanctuary join our mailing list Name * Email * sign up

September 2, 2025 2025 MAPS Bird Banding at Ruffner Mountain The MAPS (Monitoring Avian Productivity and Survivorship) Bird Banding Program is a continent-wide initiative that collects critical, long-term data on the population trends and demographic parameters for over 150 target landbird species at multiple spatial scales. In general, each participating siteâincluding Ruffner Mountain in Birmingham, Alabamaâsets up 10 fine nets at specific parameters to catch, band, and release birds in their breeding habitat, roughly every ten days through the course of the breeding season. Where possible, we provide physical access to wild spaces and unaltered natural features. In the development of new facilities, we will make every effort to be universal in our designs. If you encounter a barrier to your enjoyment of our webpage or facilities, we want to know how we can do better! If there is a reasonable accommodation that may improve your experience, we want to work with you to meet your needs. Please let us know by emailing info@jeffcogreenways.org . Privacy Policy At Jefferson County Greenways, we value and respect the privacy of our donors, members, and subscribers. We are committed to protecting your personal information and ensuring your trust in how we collect, use, and protect your data. We do not sell, rent, or trade any personal information, including contact details, donation records, or membership information, to third parties. Your information is used solely to process donations, manage memberships, and communicate with you about our work and upcoming events. We will never share your personal information without your consent, except as required by law. We take all necessary measures to safeguard your data and ensure its confidentiality. If you have any questions about how we handle your information, or if you wish to review or update your details, please contact us at info@jeffcogreenways.org .

Frequently Asked Questions - Turkey Creek Sanctuary Society QUESTIONS? Visit our FAQ page to find your answers! 321.676.6690 321.676.6690 Sign In Create Account Bookings Orders My Account Signed in as: filler@godaddy.com Bookings Orders My Account Sign out Signed in as: filler@godaddy.com Home The Nature Center Dog Policy Classes / Planks / Events Coming Events Nature Tours Donations and Store Biking at Turkey Creek Kayak Tour Volunteer Opportunities FAQ Contact Account Bookings Orders My Account Sign out Sign In Bookings Orders My Account Frequently Asked Questions Please reach us at Turkeycreekfriends@gmail.com if you cannot find an answer to your question. Can I bring my dogs to Turkey Creek? No. We only allow trained service dogs at Turkey Creek. Emotional support dogs are not trained service animals! (Please see our dog policy page for additional information.) Do you rent Kayaks? No . We do not rent kayaks. Contact: Paddling Pardise at 321.258.4492, or Palm Bay Marina at 321.723.0851 Do you charge to visit the park? No. There is no fee to visit the park. Will we see Manatee or Alligators? Maybe. Manatees and alligators are wild creatures that come and go as they please. Manatee frequent Turkey Creek, and alligators live in the creek, but we can never guarantee that you will see them. Can I bike at Turkey Creek? Our bike trails are located east of the main Sanctuary, across Turkey Creek. (Please see our biking page for directions to the bike trails.) When are you open? The park is open dawn to dusk, 365 days a year. The Nature Center is open 7 days a week from 9am to 4pm. Is there a trail map? Yes. Maps are available at our outdoor Kiosk at the park's entrance or inside the Nature Center. Can I bring a wheelchair, scooter, or stroller? Yes. Our boardwalk and some trails are suitable for wheelchairs, mobility scooters, and strollers. No other wheeled vehicles are allowed within the Sanctuary. Is it safe to walk alone in the Park? Many individuals walk the boardwalk and trails alone every day. We are fairly busy, so you are rarely totally alone. However, if you want to feel safer, the boardwalk would be your best option. Can I have an event there?                  (Wedding, birthday, memorial, etc.) Yes. You must contact the rangers to make arrangements before the event. 321.676.6690 Do you accept unwanted animals? No. We do not accept any unwanted animals. If you find injured wildlife, call "Florida Wildlife Hospital" at 321.254.8843 Can we fish at Turkey Creek? No. Fishing is not allowed from the shoreline or the boardwalk within the Sanctuary boundaries. However, fishing is permited if you are on the water in a boat. Fishing is also allowed at Ais Trail Park and Goode Park, which are both downstream from the Sanctuary. Copyright © 2023 Turkey Creek Sanctuary Society, Inc. - All Rights Reserved.
